When we discovered Sliding Rock, we had.content: When we discovered Sliding Rock, we had not bathed for days camping up in the mountains. The cold plunge pool below was totally rejuvenating.

I can remember walking around the old neighborhood wondering what water temperature would be best for washing my hair. I also thought about whether or not I would ever have it cut again. It had grown quite long while I was in school and coming back to the neighborhood after almost four years was awkward for me to say the least. I needed to find a job quick. Living in that old house again on Royal Palm Avenue with my mother wasn't an option. I wouldn't have been able to handle that for very long and as it turned out, I didn't have to. Nor did I cut my hair.
The thing about repressed memories is that they never really go away.
Thereâ€™s a number of other pleasant memories since then through the next 5 years or so but many moments in my youth thereafter were destined to become repressed memories as an adult.

To be honest, Iâ€™m not sure if it was the Delaware Bay or the Chesapeake Bay but Tony and my father had these huge cages for catching crabs and weâ€™d return [home](above%20the%20sub%20shop.md) with bushels of â€™em.
The mobile version works best in landscape mode.

It was an old step van and the passenger seat wasnâ€™t anchored. As my father drove, the seat slid forward then back then forward again. What a ride! Iâ€™m [guessing](https://ideas.joejenett.com/#shatters) I was about 10 or 11-years-old then based on the fact that Tony was with us in the van. He was a guy my father helped to immigrate from Cuba (in 1959?). We were on the way to [the bay](https://ideas.joejenett.com/#the%20bay).

content: Be inquisitive. Know what you don't know.

[follow-up: â€˜a writing app built around semantic searchâ€™](https://iwebthings.joejenett.com/follow-up-a-writing-app-built-around-semantic-search/)
How â€™bout the fact that Iâ€™m here to write this â€“ another chance to capture ideas â€“ my days are numbered. Yourâ€™s are too. Thereâ€™s nothing more clichÃ© than *thatâ€™s life*.

The web has changed but there remain remnants of what it once was in terms of personal sites. I track some of those remnants, curating such sites (which are still active, or when Iâ€™m lucky, new), hoping to somehow keep my original vision of the web intact. Itâ€™s a tough road to drive on but Iâ€™ve got a decent set of wheels with a few bells and whistles and more important, I enjoy the driving.
I think â€œthe future of awesomeâ€ really means â€œnot quite awesome yet.â€ ğŸ˜
I spent some time today improvising lyrics to a slow 4-chord progression. What fun!
Iâ€™m tickled youâ€™re here reading this. I may not know you nor get feedback but thatâ€™s okay. I still have a chance to touch you in some way with what I share â€“ what could be better than that!
